intro: Ipomopsis depressa, commonly known as the low flaxvetch, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Boraginaceae family and is characterized by its blue to purple flowers and hairy stems. The plant typically grows in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and rocky slopes. It has small, ovate leaves and produces capsule fruits that contain numerous seeds. Ipomopsis depressa is often found in arid and semi-arid regions, where it plays a role in stabilizing soil and supporting local biodiversity.
